anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended by the learned Attorney-General that the declaration of status sought in this suit by the plaintiff will be binding only upon her and the Prince, and being a rule of res judicata will bind only the parties to the suit and their privies.

issues.text: whether in a suit for declaration as regards status, the rule of present or direct interest may be relaxed where the court is of the opinion that by adding that party it would be in a better position effectually and completely to adjudicate upon the controversy

anchor.surface_text: Where the subject-matter of a litigation is a declaration as regards status or a legal character, the rule of present or direct interest may be relaxed in a suitable case where the court is of the opinion that by adding that party it would be in a better position effectually and completely to adjudicate upon the controversy.

anchor.surface_text: The Prince, in his own answer to the application for intervention, stated that he admitted that the first 1116 respondent is his wife and that the second respondent is his son, and repeated his admission by saying that lie married the plaintiff in October, 1948, and the first respondent in December 1952. He added further that when he married the first respondent, he had already three daughters by the plaintiff, which fact was known to the first respondent at the time of her marriage with him. He supported the plaintiff in her objection to the intervention by asserting that the rights of respondents 1 and 2 will not be affected in any way, and by insisting upon his Muslim right of having four wives living at the same time.

arguments.claim: Court has no jurisdiction to add respondents 1 and 2; not 'ought to have been joined' or necessary for effectual adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: In the forefront of his arguments in support of the appeal, the learned Attorney-General submitted that the court had no jurisdiction to add the first two respondents as defendants in the suit. He relied upon the words of the relevant portion of sub-rule (2) of r. 10 of O. I of the Code, which are as follows (2) and that the name of any person who ought to have been joined, whether as plaintiff or defendant, or whose presence before the Court may be necessary in order to enable the Court effectually and completely to adjudicate upon and settle all the questions involved in the suit, be added.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not question of initial jurisdiction but judicial discretion; in status suits, relax direct interest.

arguments.claim: Wife and son have no present interest in Prince's estate; expectancy does not allow intervention.

anchor.surface_text: He rightly pointed out... that the added defendants do not come within the purview of the words who ought to have been joined, which apparently have reference to necessary parties... The learned Attorney-General strenuously argued that it cannot be asserted in this case that the presence of the added defendants respondents 1 and 2 before the court was necessary... He founded this argument on the legal position that the wife and the son of the Prince respondents I and 2 have no present interest in his estate. Their expectancy of succession to the estate of the Prince does not clothe them with any right vested or contingent to intervene in this action.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ule  2  of r. 10 of O. I of the Code, which are as follows  2  and that the name of any person who ought to have been joined, whether as plaintiff or

arguments.court_reasoning: For status declarations, rule of direct interest relaxed.

arguments.claim: Narrower view of O1 r10(2): only direct interest, not commercial or indirect (citing Moser v Marsden, etc.).

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, he pointed out that r. 10 of 0. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure... has been the subject-matter of judicial interpretation in many cases... As illustrations of the former, that is to say, the narrower 1119 view, may be cited the cases of Moser v. Marsden and McCheane v. Gyles... In India, this view is represented by the decision in the case of Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varu v. The Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras.

arguments.court_reasoning: Narrower view for property; wider/relaxed for status.

arguments.claim: Even under wider view, requires direct legal interest.

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended on behalf of the appellants that whether the narrower or the wider view of the interpretation of sub-r. (2) of r. 10 of 0. I of the Code of Civil Procedure is taken, the result, so far as the present controversy is concerned, would be the same.

arguments.claim: Declaration under s42 SRA binding only on parties and privies in estate, not blood; respondents 1&2 not privies.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended by the learned Attorney-General that the declaration of status sought in this suit by the plaintiff will be binding only upon her and the Prince, and being a rule of res judicata will bind only the parties to the suit and their privies.

arguments.court_reasoning: S43 binds privies in blood for status; distinct from res judicata.

arguments.claim: Court bound to grant declaration on admission under O12 r6 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage we are only concerned with the question whether in adding respondents I and 2 as defendants in the action, the courts below have exceeded their powers.

arguments.court_reasoning: Discretionary under s42; proviso O8 r5, s58 Evidence allow proof despite admission.

arguments.claim: Addition of parties is matter of discretion, not jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Discussing the question whether it was a matter of discretion or of Jurisdiction in the court to make an order adding a party, the learned Judge made the following observations -

arguments.claim: In status declaration suits, rule of direct interest may be relaxed if presence helps effectual adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: Where the subject-matter of a litigation is a declaration as regards status or a legal character, the rule of present or direct interest may be relaxed in a suitable case where the court is of the opinion that by adding that party it would be in a better position effectually and completely to adjudicate upon the controversy.

arguments.claim: No cause of action against respondents 1&2; they have no locus standi.

anchor.surface_text: IMAM J.-I regret I cannot agree... The appellant sought no relief or any declaration against respondents 1 and 2 as, indeed, she could not have, because she had no cause of action against them. There is nothing in the pleadings of the appellant and respondent 3 which discloses that respondents I and 2 have any cause of action against the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 2  of r. 10 of 0. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, and its application to the facts of this case which are given below- On April 12, 1957, the plain

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority upheld addition despite no direct cause of action.

arguments.claim: Rights to inheritance speculative; no present rights under Muslim law; polygamy allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the appellant successfully proved that she was married to respondent 3... the status and the rights of respondents I and 2 as wife and son of respondent 3 would remain unaffected. A Mohammedan is entitled to marry more than once and have wives to the number four at one and the same time.

arguments.court_reasoning: Status affects family interests beyond property.

arguments.claim: Addition improper as no necessity under O1 r10; plaintiff entitled to choose defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The court ought not to compel a plaintiff to add a party to the suit where on the face of the plaint the plaintiff has no cause of action against him... The plaintiff is entitled to choose as defendants against whom he has a cause of action and he should not be burdened with the task of meeting a party against whom he has no cause of action.

arguments.court_reasoning: Discretion exercised properly for complete adjudication.

holdings.text: The question of addition of parties under r. 10 of O. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, is generally not one of initial jurisdiction of the court, but of a judicial discretion which has to be exercised in view of all the facts and circumstances of a particular case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes initial jurisdiction from judicial discretion; cites English and Indian cases like Moser v Marsden; applies to facts where discretion properly exercised.

holdings.text: In a suit relating to property in order that a person may be added as a party, he should have a direct interest as distinguished from a commercial interest in the subject matter of the litigation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrower view from precedents like Moser v Marsden applicable to property disputes.

holdings.text: Where the subject-matter of a litigation is a declaration as regards status or a legal character, the rule of present or direct interest may be relaxed in a suitable case where the court is of the opinion that by adding that party it would be in a better position effectually and completely to adjudicate upon the controversy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends wider view to status declarations under s42 SRA; distinguishes from property cases; promotes complete adjudication.

holdings.text: The cases contemplated in the last proposition have to be determined in accordance with the statutory provisions of ss. 42 and 43 of the Specific Relief Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Links O1 r10 to SRA provisions for declaratory suits.

holdings.text: In cases covered by those statutory provisions the court is not bound to grant the declaration prayed for, on a mere admission of the claim by the defendant, if the court has reasons to insist upon a clear proof apart from the admission.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary under s42 SRA; proviso O8 r5 CPC, s58 Evidence Act allow requiring proof despite admission.

holdings.text: The result of a declaratory decree on the question of status such as in controversy in the instant case affects not only the parties actually before the court but generations to come, and, in view of that consideration, the rule of present interest as evolved by case law relating to disputes about property does not apply with full force.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Status affects family progeny; justifies relaxing interest rule.

holdings.text: The rule laid down in s. 43 of the Specific Relief Act is not exactly a rule of res judicata. It is narrower in one sense and wider in another.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S43 binds parties and privies in blood/estate; distinct from res judicata which requires competence etc.

holdings.text: The courts below did not exceed their power in directing the addition of respondents 1 and 2 as parties-defendants in the action. Nor can it be said that the exercise of the discretion was not sound.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above propositions to facts: status suit, possible collusion, complete adjudication.

holdings.text: This case comes before us by special leave and we do not consider that it is a fit case where we should interfere with the exercise of discretion by the courts below. The appeal is, accordingly, dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave appeal; no interference with discretion.

holdings.text: A Mohammedan is entitled to marry more than once and have wives to the number four at one and the same time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial notice of Muslim personal law.

holdings.text: The Judge of the City Civil Court was justified in adding respondents 1 and 2 as parties to the suit and the decision of the High Court upholding his order should be affirmed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: no, but framed as question; dissent holds opposite.

holdings.text: There appears to be no good ground for adding respondents 1 and 2 as parties to the present suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: no necessity under O1 r10; no cause of action; speculative inheritance.

holdings.text: I would, accordingly, allow the appeal as both the courts below were in error in supposing that this was a case in which the provisions of O. 1, r. 10, applied and would set aside the orders of the courts below.

anchor.surface_text: narrower view, may be cited the cases of Moser v. Marsden 1 and McCheane v. Gyles No. 2 2 . In India, this view is represented by the decision in the case of Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varyu v. The Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras 3 . On the other side of the line, representing the wider view, may be cited the case of Dollfus Mieg Et Compagnie S. A. v. Bank of England 4

precedents.cited_proposition: narrower view of adding parties under O.1 r.10: a party not directly interested but only indirectly or commercially affected cannot be added

anchor.surface_text: In India, this view is represented by the decision in the case of Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varyu v. The Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras 3 . On the other side of the line, representing the wider view, may be cited the case of Dollfus Mieg Et Compagnie S. A. v. Bank of England 4 . In India, the decisions of the Madras High Court, in the cases of Vydianadayyan v. Sitaramayyan 5 and Secy. of State v. M. Murugesa Mudaliar 6 , were cited as illustrations. But it was contended on behalf of the appellants that whether the narrower or the wider view

anchor.surface_text: In India, the decisions of the Madras High Court, in the cases of Vydianadayyan v. Sitaramayyan 5 and Secy. of State v. M. Murugesa Mudaliar 6 , were cited as illustrations. But it was contended on behalf of the appellants that whether the narrower or the wider view of the interpretation of sub-r. 2 of r. 10 of O. I of the Code of Civil Procedure is taken, the result, so far as the present controversy is concerned, would be the same.

anchor.surface_text: The Court distinguished the previous decisions in Vavasseur v. Krupp 7 and Apollinaris Company Wilson 8 , on the ground that in those cases the litigation would have affected the property of the persons not before the court.

precedents.cited_proposition: cases where added party had property interest

anchor.surface_text: Vavasseur v. Krupp 7 and Apollinaris Company Wilson 8 , on the ground that in those cases the litigation would have affected the property of the persons not before the court. This leading case of Moser v. Marsden 1 is clearly an authority for the proposition that the court has jurisdiction to add as a party defendant only a person

precedents.cited_proposition: cases where added party had property interest

precedents.citation: Re I. G. Farbeninadusrie A. G. Agreement 1

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect is the decision in Re I. G. Farbeninadusrie A. G. Agreement 1 . The Court held that in order that a party may be added as a defendant in the suit, he should have a legal interest in the subject-matter of the litigation-legal interest not as distinguished from an equitable interest, but an interest which the law recognizes.

precedents.cited_proposition: requires legal interest, not equitable, to add party
precedents.cited_holding: court has no jurisdiction to add person without legal interest

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Vydianadayyan v. Sitaramayyan 2 , in which the wider view of the interpretation of the relevant rule was taken, Turner J. delivering the judgment of the Court, observed that the wider interpretation which enabled the court to avoid conflicting decisions on the same question and which would finally and effectually put an end to the litigation respecting it, should be adopted.

precedents.cited_proposition: wider interpretation to avoid conflicting decisions and end litigation

precedents.citation: Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varu The Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Enclowmentg, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: The two Madras decisions in Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varu The Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Enclowmentg, Madras 1 and Secy. of State v. M. Murugesa Mudaliar 2 appear to have taken conflicting views on the question whether Government could be added as a party to the litigation not because it was directly interested in the subjectmatter of the litigation, but because the law enacted by the legislature of that State had been questioned.

precedents.case_name: Sri Mahant Prayaga Doss Jee Varu v Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Endowments Madras

precedents.citation: The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum 3

anchor.surface_text: this controversy appears to have been raised in the Federal Court in the case of The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum 3 . In that case the provincial legislature of the United Provinces, as it then was, had enacted the United Provinces Regularization of Remissions Act XIV of 1938 precluding the courts from entertaining any question as to the validity of certain orders of remission of rents.

precedents.case_name: United Provinces v Mst Atiqa Begum
precedents.cited_proposition: adding government when constitutional validity questioned; jurisdiction to implead government indirectly interested

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in Moser v. Marsden 1 , Lindley L. J. observed that the question was not one of discretion but of jurisdiction . But as the antithesis shows, the learned L. J. apparently had in mind the difference between the decision of the question of joinder on the interpretation of a rule of law and a direction given by the lower court in the exercise of its discretion

precedents.cited_proposition: question of jurisdiction not discretion in adding parties

precedents.citation: Syed Ashgar Reza Khan v. Syed Mahomed Mehdi Hossein Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: reliance was placed upon the decision of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in the case of Syed Ashgar Reza Khan v. Syed Mahomed Mehdi Hossein Khan 1 . That case lays down that a decision in a former suit that the common ancestor of all the parties to the subsequent suit was entitled to the whole of the profit of a market in dispute in the two litigations, as against his co-sharers in the zamindari in which the market was situate, does not operate as res judicata

precedents.case_name: Syed Ashgar Reza Khan v Syed Mahomed Mehdi Hossein Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: decision not res judicata between claimants under common ancestor

anchor.surface_text: reliance was also placed upon a decision of the Madras High Court in the case of Vythilinga Muppanar v. Vijayathammal 2 , to the same effect.

precedents.cited_proposition: similar to Syed Ashgar on res judicata
